Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Technology Innovation for Novel Cost-reducing and Quality-enhancing Musculoskeletal Therapies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The I/UCRC for Disruptive Musculoskeletal Innovations intends to bring together expertise in medical device design; new advancements in materials, nano-technology, and medical imaging; computer modeling; clinical expertise in musculoskeletal care; business acumen for medical device innovation; and analysis of large national databases that include both clinical outcomes and cost data. By doing so, CDMI has the potential to advance knowledge by bridging these academic skills to pressing needs of the medical technology (MedTech) industry. CDMI plans to conduct research encompassing multiple disciplines, including material science, biomedical engineering, nanotechnology, biosensors, implant design, information technology, and advanced imaging that have the potential to reduce costs and improve outcomes.

The med-tech industry has an important role in the US economy. However, US pre-market regulatory processes, combined with coverage and reimbursement uncertainties, create significant deterrents to innovation, and places America?s leadership position in jeopardy. Without confidence that a new medical technology will be paid for, industry cannot justify the investment required to bring that technology to market. As a result, there is a pressing societal need to create more value from the money spent on medical technology, and thereby manage healthcare cost increases without sacrificing the benefits of innovation.
For the US to maintain its leadership in medical technologies, healthcare dollars need to be channeled in ways to foster innovation that is sustainable. The cooperative research efforts of the CDMI seek to provide, in part, a framework to achieve these ends.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall mission of the National Science Foundation (NSF) funded Center for Disruptive Musculoskeletal Innovations (CDMI) at three Institutions is to address pressing societal needs associated with the growing burden of musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs). MSDs are the second largest contributor to disability worldwide, with low back pain being the single leading cause of disability globally. Treatment for MSDs in the US, including indirect costs, was $874 billion (5.7% of GDP) in 2015. MSDs are a significant underlying factor in the current opioid epidemic, as they are the primary, non-cancerous, reason for opioid prescriptions in the US. The important research areas pursued at three sites included: characterizing MSD causal pathways; developing tools for MSD risk assessment, diagnosis, and functional recovery; predictive analytics for clinical care management; medical device design and testing; and clinical outcomes assessment with an emphasis on cost/benefit and patient value. The goal is to generate data on incidence, pathomechanisms, treatment outcomes, and costs associated with MSDs, and based on these data, develop new technologies for MSD prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. During Phase I funding, the University of Toledo - UT with expertise in Medical device design, computational modeling, empirical testing, and testing standards undertook 33 projects and published 57 research articles. During this 5-year period 38 undergraduate students were trained; 15 students were graduated with degrees (Figure 1). Some of the contributions of the university of Toledo?s research in Musculoskeletal (MSK) Research and Other Disciplines include

  • A device was developed to reduce contaminations of pedicle screws during its handling in surgery.
  •  A low-cost growth rod (device) is currently in development for the treatment of scoliosis in very young children. At present most of the growth rods costs $25K or more. Our design once fully developed would be suitable for countries with growing economies, like India, China, and Brazil as well.
  • A biomechanically-assessed new approach was developed and implemented clinically with the potential to reduce proximal junctional kyphosis (PJK) in osteoporotic spines with long fusion, using tapered bone injection concept.
  •  An orthopaedic cement technology, Novogro?, was researched and placed in the R&D 100 award winners in the country. It is intended to treat vertebral compression factures and bone tumors. The same PI also developed new biofilms for orthopedic instruments to prevent bacterial infections.
  • A new bench top testing protocol was developed to effectively test deformity-related spinal devices. The methodology will be published for other laboratories to use.
  • There have been several other biomechanical studies that have improved the testing and/or understanding of several areas: thoracic pedicle screw placement and biomechanics of patellofemoral joints, spine interbody fusion cage designs and surgical techniques, vertebral cage subsidence, and pedicle screw revision techniques. These studies will provide engineers and clinicians much insight into how to improve both device design, surgical instrumentation, and surgical techniques and thus improve patient outcomes. All of these studies have led to the development of valuable SOPs that have or will be published for other laboratories to use. 

The research under CDMI had positive impact on the Industry Advisory Board (IAB), university faculty and students. Strong interactions with faculty and IAB provided trainees insight on industry needs and provided engineering and educational understanding through applied research that will aid them with their academics and beyond into the workforce. UToledo projects connected the main and health science campuses. These projects involved in vitro testing, development of testing protocols, finite element modeling of spinal disorders/procedures, and biomaterials. The projects, required application of engineering principles in medical science and were relevant for the trainees. UToledo research complemented projects at other sites to address intellectually to most of the issues in spine, through intensive training of the students/fellows. Our university site has done exceptionally well in undertaking projects that have produced results which are adopted by the clinicians leading to reduction in the healthcare expenditure in the long run. 

The university under CDMI will continue to address the societal burden of MSDs by connecting our faculty and students with industry to translate and accelerate our research to industrial, clinical, and product improvement practices. There will be an integration of multi-disciplinary research activities at other sites, and consequently, a cross-fertilization that provides rich educational experiences for trainees. This will enhance CDMI Industry Advisory Board (IAB) access to new technologies and faculty experts, produce well-rounded students, and ultimately improve the lives of patients with MSDs.
